911.title: In the case of an active emergency, call 911.

crisis-hotlines.title: Crisis hotlines
crisis-hotlines.body:
If you are still in an actively traumatic situation, then PTSD is actually adaptive rather than maladaptive, and it's probably more pressing to work on exiting the situation or gathering resources and allies to increase your safety.

  • National Domestic Abuse Hotline
  • National Trafficking Hotline
  • Crisis Link Hotline
  • RAINN
  • National Immigration Law Center

betterhelp.title: BetterHelp
betterhelp.body:
Online counseling platform that supports weekly live sessions, unlimited messaging, and 'groupinars' for a monthly fee. They use a questionnaire to match you with a counselor within a day or two. You can request reassignment, but there are no consults to shop around before you're paired.

$70/week, billed by the month. Need-based sliding scale down to $40/week. Referral link for a free trial week.

BetterHelp seems most appropriate if you want someone you can drop messages to on your own schedule, you don't need a specialist in a particular area, and you don't feel it's important to you to get a sense of someone's conversational style before you start counseling.

psychology-today.title: PsychologyToday
psychology-today.body:
Detailed therapist search engine that lets you filter therapists by useful parameters (insurance accepted, location, specialties, treatment modalities), and provides price ranges upfront. You contact therapists individually through it to set up consults.

If paying out of pocket, expect around ~$100-180/session. Many therapists offer need-based sliding scales. Most offer free 15 minute phone consults so you can figure out if they're a good fit, ask questions, and get a feel for what it's like talking with them.

open-path-collective.title: Open Path Collective
open-path-collective.body:
Nonprofit therapy service network connecting uninsured or underinsured people with low-cost therapy.

$59 for membership, then $30–60/session. Most offer free phone consults.

therapy-den-guide.title: Beginner's Guide To Therapy | TherapyDen
therapy-den-guide.body:
Affirming guide on figuring out what kind of therapist would be a good match for you, what to ask them and yourself during a consultation, what to expect, how to tell if the therapy is working for you, and more. Some tips for getting started:

  • You can use a free consult to ask for therapist matchmaking help! Even if someone isn't a great fit, they can refer you to someone whom they think would be a better fit for you.
  • Set up consults with at least three therapists before settling. The experience of speaking with someone can't be captured in their written profile.
  • What kind of person would you personally feel most comfortable opening up to? Someone warm and nurturing? Action-oriented? A source of tough love? Serious? Humorous? It's okay to be picky.
  • Most importantly, do you feel affirmed, heard, understood, and safe with this person when you talk about your experiences and concerns? Could you develop a vulnerable rapport with them?

trigger-protocol.title: 13 Steps For Dealing With Emotional Flashbacks | Pete Walker
trigger-protocol.body:
The steps I personally start with:
  1. Recognize it is happening. Say, “I am having a flashback.”
  2. Take slow, deep breaths.
  3. Remind yourself, “I feel afraid but I am not in danger! I am safe in the present.”
  4. Identify the pattern. By noticing that the same old pattern is subtly happening again, I can better recognize what parts of it are not based in reality.

glik-therapy-modalities.title: Advice on therapy modalities | Andrea Glik
glik-therapy-modalities.body: Quick rundown of different therapy modalities, and how they might fit different needs and wants.

emotional-flashback.title: Implicit/emotional flashback
emotional-flashback.body:
Not all flashbacks involve specific memories. In an implicit flashback, the brain activates its alert system and projects scary primal emotions from an unresolved past situation onto a present-day situation which may actually not be threatening.

It is common to have implicit flashbacks to distant childhood situations where we were powerless. This can break down our safe relationships if we don't learn how to recognize the signs.

  • Applied guide to getting better at managing implicit flashbacks.
  • For the neurological explanation, see amygdala hijacking.

trigger-check.title: Are you triggered or flashbacked?
trigger-check.body:
Do you...

  • Feel overwhelmed by fear, shame, or confusion
  • Feel small, fragile, helpless, terrified
  • Feel frozen, shut down, unable to make sense of things, dissociated, emotionally numb
  • Feel enraged, critical of others, judgmental, perceive ulterior motives
  • Feel worthless, broken, self-loathing, self-disgust, self-hatred
  • Suddenly distrust your proven allies
  • Feel an evaporation of your usual self-esteem
  • Feel an overwhelming fear of catastrophe in response to a relatively mundane or innocuous situation
  • Have all-or-nothing thoughts. “People always leave”, “I can never get anything right”, etc.

Any of these may indicate you are having an implicit flashback.

Paraphrased from From Surviving To Thriving, Ch. 8. If this feels relatable, you may benefit from relational resources. See the sections on childhood and trust. If you're not sure where your triggers might stem from, you may benefit from therapy, and possibly From Surviving To Thriving, Ch. 5.

cptsd-walker.title: From Surviving To Thriving (Pete Walker)
cptsd-walker.body:
Extraordinarily actionable and affirming handbook for people who grew up with emotional neglect, repression, or abuse. Very applied, with lots of exercises and toolboxes. Structured so you can pick and choose the chapters that are relevant to you. Big focus on deprogramming Critic feelings of self-loathing, toxic shame, and perfectionist demands.

Important takeaways:

  • Emotional neglect can have a lasting impact, but isn't given as much attention as overt abuse.
  • Neglect includes: if your parents didn't show up for your emotional needs, or were incapacitated in some way.
  • It's hard to know what was missing if you never had it.

If you feel like something is wrong but you haven't sought help because you don't believe your experiences were “traumatic enough” or “other people had it worse”, there is a chapter in this book written specifically for you.

My abridged 5-page summary to try to convince anyone who's debating committing to this book.

bks.title: The Body Keeps The Score (Bessel van der Kolk)
bks.body:
Foundational overview of PTSD & cPTSD research, the neurobiology of trauma, and how somatic / mind-body integrative treatments can help dislodge stuck trauma.

My biggest takeaways:

  • Since trauma hijacks the body's survival system, even trauma with a completely non-physical origin can benefit hugely from somatic therapy.
  • Trauma is not stored in the conscious, rational part of the brain. It's fragmented in the emotional brain. Effective treatments must account for this difference.

Research-heavy. May be particularly useful if you don’t understand why your trauma is so difficult to work through, if you want to understand someone else's trauma, if you feel like you've hit a plateau in conventional talk therapy, or if you need to feel validated by research.

TW: Contains some graphic descriptions of child abuse.
Skip Part 1 if you are already familiar with the experience of having PTSD.
Part 2 focuses on the neurobiology of PTSD.
Part 5 focuses on somatic healing methods.

general-theory-love.title: A General Theory of Love (Thomas Lewis, Fari Amini)
general-theory-love.body: Great and empathetic overview of mammalian attachment, social attunement, emotional intimacy, and healthy interdependence. Extremely validating about our biological imperative for safety, understanding, co-regulation, caring, and intimacy. Extra useful if you have false core beliefs that you don't “deserve” these things.

emotionally-immature-parents.title: Adult Children of Emotionally Immature Parents (Lindsay C. Gibson)
emotionally-immature-parents.body:
Fantastic read on better understanding your childhood experiences, understanding confusing mixed signals from your caregivers, and learning to set healthy, self-respecting boundaries with your caregivers.

This book doesn’t assume a particular degree of objective badness, only that you would like to work on dysregulation of some kind. So it seems like it’d be useful for addressing a wide range of parental relationship dysfunction, from lovably frustrating to toxic.

hold-me-tight.title: Hold Me Tight (Sue Johnson)
hold-me-tight.body:
Empathetic framework for repairing dysfunctional patterns in committed relationships with an anxious-avoidant dynamic. Finds ways to gently build self-awareness of patterns, and bridge both partners’ seemingly conflicting needs for feeling safe.

This is the first book I've seen that provides empathetic insight into the needs and feelings of people with avoidant tendencies, which can often be very difficult to figure out when they are being avoidant.

Note that this framework requires a lot of vulnerability, and assumes that you are dealing with a merely dysfunctional relationship where both people truly want to put in work, and not a toxic/abusive relationship. If you think you might be in the latter situation, figure that out before proceeding.

attached-levine.title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment (Amir Levine, Rachel Heller)
attached-levine.body: An introductory overview to what attachment tendencies look like in the context of romantic relationships. I didn't personally find it as actionable, clarifying, or flexible as the resources above. I thought it demonized avoidant-leaning people in a way that didn’t seem conducive to building mutual understanding with them. Nevertheless, could be a useful intro read if your relationships have been more toxic, distressing, or inflexible.

nvc.title: Nonviolent Communication (Marshall B. Rosenberg)
nvc.body:
A communication framework rooted in deep listening and compassion to others and ourselves. Simple, memorable method to observe a situation, distinguish the objective externals from the subjective internals before we speak rashly, and move forward in mutual understanding.

Particularly useful if you're a people-pleaser, you have trouble with boundaries (yours or others’), or you wish to increase your internal emotional clarity.

crucial-conversations.title: Crucial Conversations
crucial-conversations.body: Communication skills for safely bringing up important conversations and having open dialogue. Between NVC and CC, CC seems more oriented toward anger/frustration management (‟be persuasive, not abrasive”, and NVC seems more oriented toward people-pleasers. Generally applicable to life, but CC case studies lean more often toward dialogue within workplaces and organizations.

emotional-intelligence-goleman.title: Emotional Intelligence (Daniel Goleman)
emotional-intelligence-goleman.body:
Thorough general overview on the somatic nature of emotions and hijacking. Makes a case that emotional intelligence is often much more critical for happiness, and even for very societally conventional metrics of success, than conventional intelligence is.

This book went into great depth about emotional dysregulation, but it is not a self-help book. However, it helped me better grasp the physiological nature of emotions, and validated all this time I’ve been investing into emotional regulation that I could instead be spending on more normatively “useful” things.

monique-cptsd.title: Monique Koven's CPTSD podcast
monique-cptsd.body: Comforting podcast for people with childhood trauma. Advice for holding space for yourself, meeting your missing developmental needs, and finding the right practitioners and the kind of support you need to heal. Great for normalizing big, scary experiences common to childhood trauma survivors, and figuring out what to do about them.

go-to-therapy.imageAlt: You don't have to 'qualify' for therapy. Are you a human? You qualify. Reasons to go to therapy: build insight and awareness, obtain a diagnosis, explore your history, get to know yourself, be kinder to yourself, learn coping skills, adjust to a life transition, process a past trauma, process current events, work through relationship issues, get guidance for a specific issue, have someone to talk to, grieve a loss, explore your spirituality, you are curious, you want to. From Toni Talks Therapy.

tonitalks.title: Toni Talks
tonitalks.body:
Somatic trauma educator offering tips and encouragement for getting started with therapy, shopping for a therapist, and evaluating whether a therapist is a good fit for you. Also posts basic exercises for de-triggering and mindfulness.

  • Some questions to ask a potential new therapist
  • Tips for online sessions
  • Tips for getting the most out of therapy, giving feedback, having an experimental/curious attitude

andrea-glik.title: Andrea Glik
andrea-glik.body:
Somatic trauma educator, some LGBTQ/poly content. Relatable prompts and suggestions for replacing self-destructive thought patterns with a growth mindset. Has a focus on nervous system regulation. Blogs, podcast interviews, and workshops on her website.

Instead of “I'm broken”, try “I am a trauma survivor/someone who has experienced trauma who is currently learning the impact of my experiences on my sense of self and working towards unlearning survival patterns.”

clementine-morrigan.title: Clementine Morrigan
clementine-morrigan.body:
Trauma healing writer, CSA/incest survivor, extremely LGBTQ/poly affirming. Insightful affirmations and tips for trauma-informed attachment healing and boundary navigation.

Many trauma survivors totally freeze up when we want to say no or communicate a boundary because in the past it wasn’t safe to do so. In the context of safe relationships we need to learn how to say no and communicate our boundaries. Learning to say no is part of trauma recovery. It protects our boundaries and breaks the trauma habit of going along with things we don’t want. Learning to say no is also about respecting our partner’s boundaries and understanding that safe partners don’t want to do things that their partners don’t really want. When we say no we are communicating trust and respect for our partners.

silvy-khoucasian.title: Silvy Khoucasian
silvy-khoucasian.imageAlt: Some example posts by Silvy Khoucasian on ways to communicate your needs, from attachment theory by John Bowlby and Mary Ainsworth -- if you have strong anxious tendencies or if you have strong dismissive-avoidant tendencies.
silvy-khoucasian.body: Attachment-focused coach/educator. Offers useful bite-sized prompts, tools, and perspective for people with boundary issues or childhood hangups. Also has a podcast, Love With Integrity.

liz-listens.title: Liz Listens
liz-listens.body: Attachment-focused therapy educator. Offers engaging visual paraphrases of attachment/healing frameworks (including many of the above). Helpful, concrete, and validating tips on breaking out of unhealthy patterns and being a kind person.

sit-with-sharon.title: Sit With Sharon
sit-with-sharon.imageAlt: Some example posts by Sit With Sharon of internal boundaries, and how fear of intimacy shows up.
sit-with-sharon.body: Attachment-focused therapy educator. Offers striking reframes of common dysregulated attachment mindsets. Has extremely direct tips for people with dysregulated attachment to more healthily recognize their own needs and self-harming patterns.

somatic-modalities.title: Somatic modalities
somatic-modalities.body:
Somatic therapy modalities take mind-body integration into account. They often combine physical techniques and mindfulness with talk therapy. If you are feeling stuck, overwhelmed, unpredictable, out of touch with your body, or have trauma, you may benefit from these.

Somatic experiencing, sensorimotor psychotherapy, and the Hakomi method are related treatment approaches which combine traditional therapy with developing your physical self-awareness. This helps you re-establish body agency when triggered.

These approaches can be useful for dismantling learned helplessness, improving self-awareness, learning to separate physical sensations from trauma emotions, and learning how to get out of triggered states.

EMDR is a somatic method that helps reintegrate and process stuck trauma more rapidly than conventional therapy alone. It doesn't strictly require you to describe the details of your trauma to be helpful, so it can be helpful if you have difficulty opening up to a therapist. [DOI: 10.4088/jcp.v68n0105]

EFT/tapping, involves tapping on your own body to keep it grounded in the present. This can be done on your own.

For more on how these work, see The Body Keeps The Score, Part 5.

polyvagal-overview.title: Polyvagal theory & nervous system regulation
polyvagal-overview.imageAlt: An infographic of polyvagal theory by Charissa Fry. In  the window of tolerance, or a ventral vagal activated state, we are resilient, safe, and able to socially engage and connect. In hyperarousal, or sympathetic nervous system activation, our fight or flight response is active and we are in survival mode. We can't register consequences, and may feel rage, panic, or fear. In hypoarousal, or dorsal vagal activated state, our freeze response is active and we are in survival mode. We may feel immobilized, numb, or in a trance.
polyvagal-overview.body:
infographic via Charissa Fry

Polyvagal theory describes our autonomic nervous system’s role in fight-flight-freeze responses, and how to identify and manage different states. If you often get stuck in a state of primal anger/fear/terror and you have a lot of trouble deactivating, you might find this useful.

Quick intro: Complex PTSD and the Polyvagal Theory | Polyvagal Podcast

polyvagal-rosenberg.title: Accessing the Healing Power of the Vagus Nerve (Stanley Rosenberg)
polyvagal-rosenberg.body:
Self-help exercises for improving self-regulation of your autonomic nervous system. The author comes from a craniosacral perspective.

I have not fully read this, but it comes highly recommended by a friend with physical trauma.

polyvagal-dana.title: The Polyvagal Theory in Therapy (Deb Dana)
polyvagal-dana.body:
A clinician perspective, written more for therapists looking to incorporate this approach with clients. Includes worksheets and exercises.

I have also not fully read this one yet.

tnh-intro.title: Intro to mindfulness practice by Thich Nhat Hanh
tnh-intro.body: Thich Nhat Hanh is a Buddhist monk, community leader, civilian war survivor, and extremely compassionate writer whose teachings I often find to be a gentler way of addressing inner hurts and relaxing the brain than the more direct therapy approach.

meditate-yumi.title: There Is No Right Way To Meditate (Yumi Sakugawa)
meditate-yumi.body: Small book of approachable and goofy cartoons visualizing many different ways to find ways of meditating that work for you.

engineer-mindfulness.title: An Engineer's Guide to Happiness
engineer-mindfulness.imageAlt: A flowchart illustrating meditation. Start by just inhaling and exhaling. If you get distracted, don't beat yourself up about it! Forgive yourself. It's possible to feel angry at yourself for being distracted, or even angry at your own anger. You don't need to meditate for a long time for it to be useful, but try to do it frequently!
engineer-mindfulness.body: Cute short webcomic for nerds who would like to be convinced that spending time building out an emotional toolkit will help make them more efficient in the long run.

insight-timer-app.title: Insight Timer app
insight-timer-app.body: A customizable meditation timer app with soothing sounds, plus a large library of guided meditations.

plum-village-app.title: Plum Village app
plum-village-app.body: Guided meditation app for Thich Nhat Hanh’s mindfulness teachings. Calming body scans, general awareness, and gratitude practice.

nomudnolotus.title: No Mud No Lotus (Thich Nhat Hanh)
nomudnolotus.body: A general primer on how to live mindfully in the present, as well as how to gently connect with and reassure your inner pain without feeling overwhelmed by it.

tnh-fear.title: Fear: Essential Wisdom For Getting Through The Storm (Thich Nhat Hanh)
tnh-fear.body: A more focused read on transforming the garbage of your fear, anger, and anxiety into compost to feed the flower of compassion.

janina-fisher.title: Healing The Fragmented Selves of Trauma Survivors (Janina Fisher)
janina-fisher.body:
A deep resource on processing and healing our fragmented trauma parts. Focuses on understanding traumatic responses, managing dissociation, and finding safety for all of one’s trauma parts.

Have not fully read this, but it comes highly recommended by a friend who is trained in the Hakomi Method.

boundaries-katherine.title: Where To Draw The Line (Anne Katherine)
boundaries-katherine.body: Boundaries aren't just for fending off toxic people; they can also be used to nourish ourselves and increase trust and intimacy when communicated with enough clarity and kindness. Guidance for navigating and holding many kinds of healthy boundaries, with strangers, friends, partners, relatives, coworkers, etc.

self-boundaries.title: How are your boundaries?
self-boundaries.body:
If you feel bad in your emotions and aren't sure why, it's possible you have overextended your boundaries without realizing it, or neglected your own emotional needs. These influences might not be Bad -- just not what you need or maybe more than you can handle right now.

Do you...

  • Feel like you are giving a lot more than you receive?
  • Feel drained by certain interactions?
  • Feel chronically ignored, invalidated, or unvalued?
  • Feel pressured (whether explicitly or implicitly) to do things you have a core discomfort with?

If so, you might benefit from clarifying your boundaries and core needs. Most of us, especially BIPOCs, don't have the privilege to safely enforce all our boundaries. But most of us can at least improve our close relationships through more explicit boundary communication. Toxic boundary violation is one thing, but it's also surprisingly common for others to accidentally step on our boundaries because we don't even know what our own boundaries are.

Paraphrased from resources in the section on healthy boundaries.

gift-of-fear.title: The Gift of Fear (Gavin de Becker)
gift-of-fear.body:
On re-harnessing survival intuition repressed by social norms. Not conducive to PTSD healing, but seems useful for helping you reconnect with your self-preservation instincts if you are particularly susceptible to gaslighting and don't trust your gut.

I don't unilaterally recommend this read as it encourages a bit of paranoia, trusting snap judgments, and hypervigilance. It's more of a push to help you overcome your mental aversion to GTFO of a genuinely dangerous situation (stalking, abuse, exploitation, threats, very unnerving behavior from someone).

was-it-abuse.title: “But I wasn't abused”
was-it-abuse.body:
1. Abuse comes in many different forms.
  2. You can have trauma without abuse.
  3. If you were abandoned, chronically neglected, enmeshed, or expected to repress certain feelings as a child, you can develop lasting trauma from that.

chronic-neglect.title: Chronic emotional neglect
chronic-neglect.body:
If you chronically experienced any of these factors growing up or in a long-term codependent relationship, they have probably significantly shaped your self-image and ways of relating to others:

  • Being ridiculed/punished for crying, or for other ways of healthily expressing feelings
  • Being treated with disgust or contempt
  • Being rejected or invalidated when you wanted comfort for pain
  • Being abandoned without explanation, or when you were too young to understand
  • Being constantly compared to “perfect” ideals
  • Your aspirations were treated as wasteful or unimportant
  • Not being allowed privacy
  • Being expected to do things for others that you felt deeply uncomfortable doing
  • Parentification: being forced to become a parent's caretaker (especially emotionally) while still in childhood

Paraphrased from Pete Walker's CPTSD book, Ch.5. If this feels relatable, you'll probably benefit from relational resources.

attachment-theory.title: Attachment theory
attachment-theory.body:
Posits that we all share a common goal of wanting safety from an intimate bond when stressed. But our instinctive ways of seeking safety can be wildly different based on our formative emotional experiences, often from our childhood caregivers or lack thereof.

For example, we may feel unsafe without constant reassurance (anxious tendencies), or may feel unsafe with intimacy (avoidant tendencies), or simultaneously seek out and fear closeness (fearful-avoidant / disorganized tendencies). This often has self-destructive effects that undermines the very safety we seek.

Fortunately, it is possible to change attachment styles. The ultimate goal is being comfortable with intimacy, but also not panicking if we don't have constant reassurance (secure attachment).

alexithymia.title: Alexithymia
alexithymia.body: The inability to identify emotions (in oneself or others). For some people, this can be true all the time. But even if you’re usually fine at identifying emotions, it’s not uncommon to lose the ability if you're feeling triggered or overwhelmed.

hijacking.title: Emotional hijacking
hijacking.body: The amygdala is our center of emotional memory and survival alarms. It makes snap judgments a lot faster than our neocortex can make complex decisions. In other words, there’s a physiological explanation as to why rationalizations might not help us think straight when we're scared, triggered, or angry.

interoception.title: Interoception
interoception.body: Awareness of one’s internal physiological state.

simple-soothing.title: Simple self-soothing
simple-soothing.body:
• Slow, deep breathing helps calm the body's threat response.
  • Safe touch can help you remember your body is in the present. Hugs, hand-holding, self-hugging, a plush, a weighted blanket, a palm stone, a tree, a fidget object, etc.
  • Music that makes you feel safe.

wildfell-consensuality.title: Consensuality: Navigating Feminism, Gender, and Boundaries Towards Loving Relationships (Helen Wildfell)
wildfell-consensuality.body:
Anecdotes and exercises about overcoming dysfunctional boundaries and communicating healthily about consent, conflict, and emotional expression.

Do you feel capable of expressing how you feel on the inside? Do the people close to you try to restrict your expression of how you feel? What are some healthy ways of manifesting and expressing these feelings?

crabb-ethical-consent.title: Learning Good Consent: Building Ethical Relationships in a Complicated World (Cindy Crabb)
crabb-ethical-consent.body:
Anecdotes and prompts to help you define your comfort zone, what consent means for you, and how you approach other people's consent.

How might someone express that what is happening is not ok? Do you look only for verbal signs or are there other signs? How do you react if someone becomes uncomfortable with what you're doing, or if they don't want to do something?

tnh-love.title: How To Love (Thich Nhat Hanh)
tnh-love.body:
Small book of refreshingly simple analogies and insights on practicing genuine empathy, kindness, and respect with ourselves and those around us.

A wrong perception can be the cause of a lot of suffering. This is why, whenever we have a perception, we have to ask ourselves if our perception is right.

elleanderson.title: Laura Anderson
elleanderson.imageAlt: 1. The moment we begin comparing our traumas OR how we are processing our trauma is the moment that shame begins. 2. Trauma becomes worse when we disconnect from ourselves and others. From Laura Anderson.
elleanderson.body:
Trauma educator offering tips on finding a therapist who really understands you, info about what you should be able to expect from a trauma-informed therapist, and affirmations about the more frustrating aspects of the healing process. (Specializes in complex trauma and cult trauma.)

  • Therapists should recognize that you are the expert on your life
  • On prioritizing your feelings of safety during a session
  • The difference between treating trauma vs. treating symptoms

pocketselfcare.title: Pocket Self-Care Manual (fill it out yourself)
pocketselfcare.imageAlt: Photo of a Choose Your Own Adventure Pocket Self-Care Manual.
pocketselfcare.body:
It can be frustratingly difficult to remember the basic self care steps, coping mechanisms, and affirmations that help most when I need them most, so I made a pocket self-care manual to help lock those things in.

Offers prompts that you provide your own answers to, because no one else can tell you what works best for yourself! Wait until you're feeling relatively safe to fill it out.

complex-trauma-infographics.title: Complex Trauma Healing
complex-trauma-infographics.imageAlt: Chart of the 4F personality types (Fight, Flight, Freeze, Fawn).
complex-trauma-infographics.body: A blog of infographics summarizing dense information from key complex trauma resources.

love-languages.title: 5 Love Languages
love-languages.body:
The concept of love languages states that we receive and show love in different ways (quality time, gifts, acts of service, physical touch, words of affirmation), where some of those ways will actually feel like love to us, and others might not.

For example, someone might give a lot of fancy, expensive gifts to someone who only wants more quality time, and then feel resentful because they're putting in so much effort that doesn't seem to be improving the relationship.

By communicating with our loved ones what love languages feel most personally special to them and us, we can better understand, give, and receive actions as expressions of love.

reassurance-box.title: Reassurance box
reassurance-box.body:
If you need frequent reassurance to feel safe, and would like to practice self-soothing more, it can be helpful to make a box or digital folder full of reassurances that you can go through any time. Some ideas:

  • screenshots of deeply reassuring or encouraging messages
  • reminders of reassuring things that loved ones have done for you, or times you felt safe
  • voice messages or photos from loved ones that make you feel good
  • reminders of ways you are safe now
  • written-out reasons why you know you can trust your allies
  • if worried about unpredictable events, written-out reasons & motivations to appreciate what you have in the present

whats-therapy-like.imageAlt: What I thought would happen in therapy: talk about my feelings, learn some coping skills, get advice. What actually happens in therapy: develop a cohesive life narrative, integrate the different versions of myself, have my value and worth unconditionally acknowledged, have my experiences validated, break patterns of generational trauma, have space to come to my own value-driven conclusions, experience a relationship with healthy boundaries, become aware of my self-talk and learn to talk back, have emotionally corrective experiences, make the unconscious conscious, resolve internal conflicts, cultivate self awareness and emotional intelligence. From Dr. Megan Johnson.

conscious-uncoupling.title: Conscious Uncoupling (Katherine Woodward Thomas)
conscious-uncoupling.body:
Incredibly actionable, emotionally affirming, and compassionate guide on how to mindfully transform relationship-transition grief and pain into an intentional commitment toward mutual kindness, examining your own unhealthy patterns, and learning how to become your most authentic and loving self. Can be used for navigating ongoing processes, or for healing older breakup scars.

Caveat: Since fully standing up for your authentic self requires a certain degree of security in your basic survival needs, it's worth noting that some of the self-empowerment framings in this book might feel invalidating if you currently have very little logistical agency, have recently been abused, or are still in an actively unsafe situation.

pubmed-cptsd-efficacy.title: Analysis of the inefficacy of evidence-based treatments for complex trauma
pubmed-cptsd-efficacy.body:
A PubMed validation for anyone who feels bad that they still have trauma and their progress has plateaued with “established” trauma treatment methodologies. Many expert-sanctioned approaches to complex trauma are “alternative”, because effective complex trauma treatments are intrinsically only partially compatible with scientific rigor.

Why?

  • Complex trauma has many comorbidities. Comorbidities must be eliminated if rigor is of higher priority than efficacy. As a result, complex trauma is underrepresented in studies.
  • Non-complex trauma receives more study funding because it is more economical to resolve, and has fewer comorbidities.
  • It is literally not possible to fully blind a study that involves using personalized psychotherapy as a treatment.

Choice excerpts from the article:

  • Complex presentations are often excluded from studies because they do not fit neatly into the simple nosological categorisations required for research power. This means that the most severe disorders are not studied adequately and patients most affected by early trauma are often not recognised by services.
  • If research funding is not readily accessible for complex and prolonged interventions that are clinically applied in the phase-based treatment of complex PTSD, it is easy to arrive at the false conclusion that a lack of evidence for a particular therapy indicates that it is not effective.
  • Women were also excluded from the study if they were in a relationship with an abusive partner, a situation unfortunately all too common in this clinical population.
  • The lack of evidence is not an indicator that particular approaches do not work – only that they have not been rigorously tested. Testing procedures understandably but unhelpfully prefer simple, measurable attributes for economy of scale.

maps.title: MAPS (Multidisciplinary Association For Psychedelic Studies)
maps.body: A research & educational organization whose top priority is developing MDMA-assisted psychotherapy into a legal, FDA-approved PTSD treatment.

reddit-crisis.title: r/CPTSD crisis resources
reddit-crisis.body: Extensive community-organized collection of crisis, support, and emotional first-aid resources.

whats-cptsd.title: CPTSD
whats-cptsd.body:
CPTSD, or complex trauma, is a term for a set of symptoms resulting from prolonged trauma combined with interpersonal dependence where the victim has little chance of escaping. This creates co-morbidities, so people with CPTSD are often misdiagnosed with other conditions. Because CPTSD is not in the DSM, you cannot be officially diagnosed with it.

CPTSD is often associated with (but not limited to) survivors of chronic childhood abuse or neglect, concentration camps, trafficking, or cults.

grounding-first-aid.title: Grounding & emotional first aid
grounding-first-aid.body: Collection of somatic grounding exercises to help you de-escalate out of a triggered state.

identify-triggers.title: Learn to identify your trigger signs
identify-triggers.body:
The most important first step is to quickly identify when you are triggered, so you can remember to use your tools. It can be hard to recognize your more subtle triggers until they get out of control.

I find it helpful to keep a journal to find early warning signs and common threads. Some questions to ask yourself:

  • How does my body feel? Where is the trigger feeling located?
  • What are my extreme, all-or-nothing thoughts during this trigger? (“I'm worthless”, “I can never do anything right for them”, etc.)
  • Do I have ideas what the earliest root cause of this trigger is?

Informed by From Surviving To Thriving, Ch. 8. Highly recommend the entire book if you want to learn more about finding and resolving your trigger sources.

effective-cptsd.title: What makes an effective CPTSD treatment plan?
effective-cptsd.body:
• Neuroscientifically credible, even if we don't understand the exact healing mechanism.
  • Somatically informed. Trauma hijacks the body.
  • Holistic. Complex trauma is complex; there is often no pre-existing 'healthy' state to heal back to, and no single magic bullet.
  • Relationally informed. CPTSD is partially an attachment disorder, and requires relational healing.

Drawn from Surviving To Thriving, and Parts 2 and 5 of The Body Keeps The Score.

cptsd-workbook-schwartz.title: The Complex PTSD Workbook (Arielle Schwartz)
cptsd-workbook-schwartz.body:
A workbook to normalize, process, and tackle lingering emotional hangups from childhood. A compact tasting course to the many frameworks, concepts, and treatments relevant to childhood dysregulation. Prompts and exercises to feel out what frameworks stick or feel personally relevant to you.

You are not broken, in need of fixing. Rather, you are deeply hurt, in need of care.

relational-healing.title: If you have difficulty trusting humans at all
relational-healing.body:
Ways to increase your relational capacity without direct human contact:

  • Nature or gardening
  • Taking care of animals
  • Reading validating self-help books or cathartic fiction
  • Art & writing by people with similar emotional baggage
  • Movement arts to increase your comfort with your body (yoga, flow arts, dance)

Slowly easing into human relational healing:

  • Receiving unconditional positive regard from a therapist
  • Support groups (in person or online)

heather-tuba.title: Heather Tuba
heather-tuba.body: Tips for partners/supporters of people with CPTSD.

trigger-support.title: Helping with emotional first-aid
trigger-support.body:
It's really difficult to communicate effectively when triggered. Depending how much internal work the person has done, it might be emotionally or even physically difficult for them to say what they need, and sometimes no amount of verbal reassurance can help. You can help someone you care about by:

  • Learning to recognize their trigger signs
  • Learning what's happening to them (what do they fear? are they frozen? numb? self-blaming? angry? do they need more space, or do they need to not be alone?)
  • Knowing what helps them de-escalate (deep breathing, a hug, quiet, music, etc.)
  • Taking time-outs
  • Being present and deeply listening to their pain
  • Supporting them in seeking therapy or other external support

(Make sure you aren't neglecting your own needs, especially if you're also triggered.)

tiny-god.title: Tiny God
tiny-god.body: An adorable, business-card-sized set of prompts for imagining a tiny, mindful witness who follows you around and is very interested in all your feelings and what you have to say.

consent-madlib.title: Consent Madlib
consent-madlib.body: The yes-no threshold can be in very different places for people with healthy boundaries vs. people who have been conditioned by fear, guilt, or shame. A simple visual guide I made to help untangle different levels of wantingness.

walker-conflict-resolution.title: Tips for lovingly resolving conflict
walker-conflict-resolution.body: Pete Walker's tips for lovingly normalizing and resolving interpersonal conflict. Includes tips on how to use time-outs, helping both people get their feelings heard, staying self-aware, and holding yourself accountable.

self-education.title: Self-education & self-awareness
self-education.body:
Other people can't possibly know about your underlying feelings and wants if you don't clearly communicate them, and you can't communicate your feelings and wants to others if you don't understand yourself well in the first place.

Understanding and acknowledging your emotional baggage and how it affects you is the first step in improving your communication.

samaran-shame.title: Connection in Practice: Tricks of Shame & Hope | Nora Samaran
samaran-shame.body: Article on deprogramming shame, guilt, and feelings of inadequacy. These prevent us from authentically connecting, and from recognizing the ways people show us that they value us.

samaran-autonomy.title: For Men Who Desperately Want Autonomy | Nora Samaran
samaran-autonomy.body: An article on balancing autonomy and intimacy for masculine-identified people in relationships. By being generally emotionally reliable, you can safely receive both intimacy and autonomy.

reparenting.title: “Reparenting the Inner Child”
reparenting.body:
The process of discovering your unmet developmental needs, where healthy behavior was never properly modeled for you, and learning how to meet those needs for yourself. If you never had something growing up, it's hard to know what's missing.

If we grew up with core beliefs that we were defective, unlovable, worthless, or incapable, we may feel broken inside, treat ourselves badly, and crave stimulation, distraction, or approval to feel temporarily better. As long as we haven't addressed the core issues, we will continue craving endlessly without truly feeling better inside, even if our specific addictions are treated.

By reparenting, you gain self-respect, self-awareness, personal responsibility, internal security, and confidence to take care of your feelings and needs. You realize that you are the only person who can healthily be present for yourself 100% of the time.

For a great framework for processing your needs, see From Surviving To Thriving.
For reparenting scripts & troubleshooting help, check out Healing Your Aloneness.

healing-aloneness.title: Healing Your Aloneness (Margaret Paul)
healing-aloneness.body:
A guide to reparenting yourself to heal your core abandonment pain, with a lot of useful scripts, encouragement, and guides to get unstuck from common roadblocks (such as fear of your own anger, fear of being fully responsible for yourself, and fear of failing to improve).

I found about half the book (Chapters 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10) very applied and useful, and I didn't benefit much from the other half. FYI, the book also made some queer-phobic remarks, and felt socially dated.
